questions.explanation: A set of principles and values for software development that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and iterative progress.
A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
A set of rules and protocols that allows software applications to communicate with each other.
A data structure that stores a fixed-size sequential collection of elements of the same type.
A field of computer science that focuses on creating intelligent machines capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence.
A character encoding standard that assigns unique numeric codes to represent characters from various writing systems.

options.answer: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange)

questions.explanation: A low-level programming language that uses mnemonic codes to represent machine instructions.
A statement that verifies the correctness of a condition or value.
The server-side of a client-server architecture where the logic and processing of an application reside.
A term used to describe extremely large and complex datasets that cannot be easily managed and processed using traditional methods.
A base-2 numeral system in which numeric values are represented using only two symbols: 0 and 1.
The smallest unit of data in computing, representing either a 0 or 1.
A distributed ledger technology that allows multiple parties to have a shared, immutable record of transactions.
A data type that represents one of two possible truth values: true or false.
An error or defect in a software program that prevents it from functioning as intended.
A unit of digital information storage, typically consisting of 8 bits.
A hardware or software component that stores data to reduce the amount of time it takes to fetch the data from the main memory.
A blueprint or template for creating objects that define their properties and behaviors.
A method of delivering computing services over the internet on-demand, such as storage, processing power, and databases.
Instructions or commands written by a programmer in a programming language.
A program that translates source code written in a high-level language into machine code that can be executed by a computer.
A reusable and self-contained piece of software that encapsulates a specific functionality or set of behaviors.
The practice of securing communication and information by transforming it into an unreadable format using encryption techniques.

A structured collection of data that is organized and accessible in various ways.
The process of identifying, fixing, and removing errors, bugs, or malfunctions in a software program.
The act of declaring a variable by specifying its name and data type before it is used in a program.
A relationship between two software components in which one component depends on the other to function correctly.
A general reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software design.
A set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten the systems development life cycle and deliver software faster and more reliably.
A hierarchical decentralized naming system that translates domain names (e.g., www.example.com) to IP addresses.
A platform that enables developers to build, package, distribute, and run applications and services using containers.
A written or visual representation of how to use, operate, maintain, or troubleshoot a system or software.
An approach to software development that focuses on the core domain of a problem, aligning the implementation closely with the business requirements.
An integrated development environment (IDE) widely used for Java programming.
The process of converting plaintext into ciphertext to secure it from unauthorized access or use.
A specific URL or URI that an API exposes to enable communication and interaction with the underlying software or system.
A data type that consists of a set of named values, where each value represents a unique constant.
The process of detecting, handling, and recovering from errors or exceptional situations that occur during the execution of a program.
A security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
A set of tools, libraries, and best practices that provide a foundation for developing software applications.
The part of a software system or application that is directly accessed and used by the user.
A named block of code that performs a specific task and can be invoked (called) from other parts of the program.

A user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and visual indicators.

A software application that provides comprehensive facilities for computer programming, editing, and debugging.
A mechanism by which one class inherits the properties (methods and fields) of another class.
A data type that represents a whole number without any fractional or decimal part.
A programming construct that defines a set of methods that a class must implement.
A network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies to enable the exchange of data and automation of tasks.
A unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network that uses the Internet Protocol for communication.
The process of repeating a set of instructions or steps in a program until a specific condition is met or a termination criteria is satisfied.
A popular general-purpose programming language known for its simplicity, versatility, and compatibility.
A versatile programming language commonly used for web development and client-side scripting.
An open-source automation server widely used for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) of software projects.
A lightweight data interchange format commonly used for transmitting data between a server and a web application.
A virtual machine that executes Java bytecode, enabling Java programs to run on any platform that has a JVM implementation.
A feature in programming languages that allows the creation of anonymous functions or functions without a defined name.
A collection of precompiled and reusable code that can be used by multiple programs or modules.
A linear data structure in which elements are linked together using pointers or references.
An open-source operating system kernel based on the Unix operating system.
A field of study and practice that focuses on the development of algorithms and statistical models that enable computer systems to learn and improve from experience.
A large, powerful, and expensive computer used mainly by large organizations for critical applications and bulk data processing.
A programming model and software framework commonly used for processing and analyzing large volumes of data in a distributed computing environment.
A situation in which a computer program or system fails to release memory that is no longer needed, causing a gradual reduction in available memory.
A named block of code that performs a specific task and can be invoked (called) by name.
An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services that can be independently developed, deployed, and scaled.
Software that sits between different software applications or components, providing communication and data management services.
The process of developing software applications for mobile devices, such as smartphones and tablets.
A software architectural pattern commonly used for designing user interfaces, where the application logic is divided into three interconnected components: model, view, and controller.
A self-contained unit of functionality that can be independently developed, tested, and deployed.
The concurrent execution of multiple threads within a single program.
An open-source relational database management system known for its reliability, scalability, and performance.
A mechanism in programming languages that allows the same name to be used for multiple functions or methods with different parameters.

A way to organize and group related classes, interfaces, and resources in a program.

The process of evaluating the performance or capabilities of a software product under specific conditions.

A concept in object-oriented programming that allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass.

A set of rules and standards that govern the format and transmission of data between two or more devices.
A versatile programming language known for its simplicity and readability, widely used for web development, scientific computing, data analysis, artificial intelligence, and more.
A data structure that follows the FIFO (First-In-First-Out) principle.
A type of computer memory that allows data to be accessed in any order with a constant access time.
A popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
A programming technique in which a function calls itself to solve a problem by dividing it into smaller subproblems.
The process of restructuring existing code or software to improve its internal structure, without changing its external behavior.
A sequence of characters that defines a search pattern, used for matching or manipulating strings.
An architectural style for designing networked applications, typically used in web services development, that emphasizes scalability, simplicity, and statelessness.
A statement in a programming language that is used to return a value or result from a function or method.
A dynamic, reflective, object-oriented programming language known for its simplicity and productivity.
An iterative and incremental framework for managing product development, commonly used in agile software development.
A set of software development tools and libraries that allows the creation of applications for a specific platform or operating system.
A type of testing that focuses on evaluating the security of a system or application by identifying vulnerabilities, weaknesses, and potential threats.
A computer or device on a network that manages network resources and provides services to clients.
An architectural style for designing software applications as a collection of loosely coupled and reusable services.
A design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to a single object, ensuring that only one instance of the class exists.
An algorithm that puts elements of a list in a certain order, such as numerical or lexicographical order.
A standard language for interacting with relational databases, used for managing, manipulating, and querying data.
A linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last-In-First-Out) principle.
The process of analyzing source code or compiled code to identify and report potential issues, bugs, or code smells.
A sequence of characters.
A user-defined composite data type in some programming languages.
A named sequence of instructions that performs a specific task and can be invoked (called) from other parts of a program.

The set of rules and structure that define the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs or expressions in a programming language.

A specific set of conditions or variables under which a tester will determine whether a system or application satisfies the requirements or works correctly.
The process of evaluating a system or component by manual or automated means to verify that it satisfies specified requirements.
A separate flow of execution within a program, allowing multiple tasks to be performed concurrently.
A strongly typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript.
The visual part of a computer program or website with which a user interacts.
A computing industry standard for the consistent encoding, representation, and handling of text expressed in most of the world's writing systems.

options.answer: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange)

questions.explanation: A family of operating systems that are Unix-like and based on the original Unix system.
A standardized general-purpose modeling language for specifying, visualizing, constructing, and documenting the artifacts of a software system.
A string of characters that identifies the location of a resource on the internet.
A named storage location in a program that can hold a value, which can be modified during the execution of the program.
The management of changes to documents, computer programs, large web sites, and other collections of information.
A software program or emulation of a physical machine that runs programs like a physical computer.
The creation or maintenance of applications that run in a web browser or on a web server.
A markup language used for describing the structure and presentation of web pages.
A markup language designed for storing and transporting data.
A human-readable data serialization format commonly used for configuration files and data exchange between languages with different data structures.
The process of reducing complex or abstract ideas to simpler representations, models, or concepts.
The evaluation of a product or system at the end of the development process to determine whether it satisfies specified requirements.
A testing technique where the tester has complete knowledge of the internal workings of the item being tested.
A software testing technique in which the internal workings of the item being tested are unknown to the tester.
A methodology or approach to software development that emphasizes collaboration, iterative development, and flexibility in responding to change.
A document that describes how a software product should behave in various scenarios or conditions.
A security testing technique that determines whether an application is susceptible to attacks that may compromise its security.
A specialized server computer used to store and manage data and serve it to other computers over a network.
An architectural style for building software systems that rely on a collection of loosely coupled services to support business processes.
A design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to a single instance and provides a global point of access to it.
A sorting algorithm that works by repeatedly dividing the unsorted list into smaller sublists and then merging them in the correct order.
A domain-specific language used for managing and querying relational databases.
A linear data structure in which elements are added and removed from the same end, often referred to as the top.
The process of analyzing computer software in order to identify coding errors, security vulnerabilities, and other issues.
A sequence of characters.
A composite data type that groups together zero or more values with different types.
A sequence of program instructions that performs a specific task, packaged as a unit.
The coordination of events to operate in a synchronized manner, especially in multi-threaded programs.
The set of rules that define the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured statements or expressions in a programming language.
A set of protocols that allows computers to communicate over networks.
A set of conditions or variables under which a tester will determine if a system under test satisfies requirements or works correctly.
The process of evaluating a system or component with the intent to find whether it satisfies the specified requirements or not.
A sequence of instructions within a process that can be scheduled and executed independently by a computer's operating system.
A programming language that is a typed superset of JavaScript, which compiles to plain JavaScript.
The visual and interactive part of a software application or system that allows users to interact with it.
A universal character encoding standard that aims to provide a unique numeric value for every character across all writing systems and languages.

options.answer: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange)

questions.explanation: A family of multitasking, multiuser computer operating systems that derive from the original AT&T Unix.
A standardized modeling language used in software engineering to visually represent systems, structures, behaviors, and interactions of software systems.
A string of characters that identifies the location of a resource on the internet.
A named storage location in computer memory that can hold a value, which can be modified during the program execution.
The management of changes to documents, source code, or other collections of information, ensuring that different versions are controlled and tracked.
A software implementation that behaves like a physical computer and runs programs as if they were executing on a real computer.
An application or program that runs on a web browser and is accessed over a network, typically the internet.
The process of designing, creating, and maintaining websites and web applications.
A markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
A human-readable data serialization language commonly used for configuration files and data exchange between languages with different data structures.
A concept in object-oriented programming that focuses on representing the essential characteristics of an object, while hiding unnecessary details.
The process of evaluating a software application or system's ease of use and accessibility for people with disabilities.
A scripting language primarily used for web development and the development of Adobe Flash content.
A set of technologies developed by Microsoft that enables software components to interact with one another in a networked environment.
An informal and improvisational approach to software testing, where tests are designed and executed spontaneously.
A set of guiding values and principles for agile software development, emphasizing collaboration, adaptability, and continuous improvement.
A set of web development techniques that allow web applications to send and receive data asynchronously, typically using JSON or XML.
The initial phase of software testing where a software product is tested by the developers before it is released to external users.
A cloud computing platform provided by Amazon that offers a broad set of services and infrastructure to build, deploy, and manage applications and services.
The process of discovering, interpreting, and communicating meaningful patterns in data.
An open-source operating system primarily used on mobile devices, based on the Linux kernel.
A standardized programming language that follows the ANSI C standard.
Documentation that provides information about the programming interfaces of a software component or system.
A software framework that provides the necessary infrastructure and services to host and manage web applications.
A value or data passed to a function, procedure, or command-line program.
A programming paradigm that aims to increase modularity, reusability, and maintainability by separating cross-cutting concerns into distinct modules.
A software testing technique where specific conditions or properties of a program are checked to ensure they hold true.
A low-level programming language that closely resembles the machine language of a specific computer architecture.
A low-level programming language that uses mnemonics to represent machine instructions.
A statement or predicate that is expected to be true at a particular point in a program's execution.
The process of automatically executing software tasks, typically performed by specialized tools or scripts.

A class from which other classes are derived, inheriting its properties and methods.

Set of guidelines, techniques, and programming patterns that represent the most effective ways to write code for a specific programming language or framework.

A tree-like data structure in which each node has at most two children, referred to as the left child and the right child.
Operations that manipulate individual bits within a byte or other data unit.
A type of software testing that focuses on finding vulnerabilities related to incorrect or unexpected handling of memory buffers.
The process of tracking and managing software bugs or issues from detection to resolution.
The process of automating the tasks involved in building, testing, and deploying software.
An intermediate representation of a program that can be executed by a virtual machine.
A programming language known for its high-level abstraction and a wide range of applications, developed at Bell Labs in the 1970s.
A general-purpose programming language that supports various programming paradigms and is widely used in systems programming and game development.
A type of high-speed memory used by a computer's processor to store frequently accessed data.
A naming convention in which the first letter of each compound word or phrase is capitalized, except for the first word, which starts with a lowercase letter.
A challenge-response test used to determine whether the user is a human or an automated program.

options.answer: CAPTCHA (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart)

questions.explanation: Software tools designed to support one or more activities of the software development process.
A highly scalable and distributed NoSQL database management system known for its ability to handle large amounts of data across multiple commodity servers.
The combination of continuous development (CD) and continuous integration (CI), which refers to the practice of automatically building, testing, and deploying software changes.
A visual representation of the structure and relationships of classes in a system, typically used in object-oriented modeling.
The practice of writing code that is easy to understand, read, and maintain, often following specific guidelines and principles.
A type of architecture in which the client-side and server-side components of an application are distributed across different machines.
A method of storing and accessing data over the Internet instead of locally on a computer or other storage device.
A software system that facilitates the creation, modification, and publication of digital content on the web.
A metric used to measure the extent to which the source code of a program has been tested.
The process of reviewing code to identify and correct errors, improve quality, and ensure compliance with coding standards.
A characteristic or pattern in the source code that may indicate a deeper problem or design flaw.
A means of interacting with a computer program or system through textual commands entered in a command-line interface.
A text or annotation added to a section of code, providing explanatory information or indicating the purpose of the code.
A record of changes made to a repository, typically in version control systems like Git.
The process of transforming source code to improve its efficiency, speed, or other characteristics without changing its external behavior.
The study of the computational resources required to solve a given computational problem, typically measured in terms of time and space complexity.
A field of study that focuses on enabling computers to see, interpret, and understand visual data or images.
A programming paradigm that allows multiple concurrent threads of execution to share resources and communicate with each other.
A software development practice that focuses on delivering software in short cycles, ensuring that it can be released quickly and frequently.
The practice of merging code changes from multiple contributors into a central repository frequently and regularly.
The flow of execution in a program, determined by the order in which individual statements, instructions, or function calls are executed.
Testing approach that focuses on identifying issues related to concurrent execution of code.
A piece of data that is stored on a user's computer by a web browser, typically used for session management or tracking.
A parallel computing platform and application programming interface (API) model created by NVIDIA for utilizing the power of GPUs.
A custom-defined exception that is created to handle specific error conditions in a program.
A concept in object-oriented programming that allows hiding the internal implementation details of data and providing only necessary interfaces.
The process of inspecting, transforming, and modeling data to discover useful information, patterns, and relationships.
The process of converting data into a form that cannot be easily understood or accessed by unauthorized parties.
The assurance that data remains unaltered, complete, and accurate throughout its lifecycle.
The process of discovering patterns and relationships in large datasets to extract useful information.
A way of organizing and storing data in a computer's memory or disk, designed to facilitate efficient access and modification.
A classification or category of data that determines the possible values and operations that can be performed on it.
The process of validating and verifying data to ensure that it conforms to certain rules, constraints, or standards.
A software system that manages and organizes databases, providing functions for storing, retrieving, and manipulating data.
A tool or software used by developers to identify and resolve issues or bugs in a program.
A statement in a programming language that declares a variable or constant with a specific data type.
A programming technique that focuses on writing code that anticipates and handles possible errors and exceptions.
A design pattern that allows the injection of dependencies into an object, making it more flexible and easier to test.
A graph traversal algorithm that explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.
A software development approach that emphasizes specifying and enforcing formal contracts between components.
A document that describes the design specifications, architecture, and requirements of a software system.
A general reusable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software design.
An application that is run on a desktop or laptop computer, typically with a graphical user interface.
The environment in which software development is carried out, including tools, libraries, and frameworks.
A diagram that represents the flow of data within a system, showing how inputs are transformed into outputs.
An algorithm for finding the shortest path between nodes in a graph.
A hierarchical structure used to organize files and directories in a computer system.
A model of computation where tasks are divided among multiple computers connected over a network.
A library or module that contains precompiled code and data that can be used by multiple programs.
The unique name that identifies a website on the Internet.
A legacy operating system that was widely used on IBM-compatible personal computers.
A programming language specifically designed to address the needs of a particular domain or problem domain.
A programming language feature that allows objects of different types to be treated as if they share a common interface.
A method of analyzing software by executing it with sample inputs to observe its behavior.
A programming technique that involves breaking down a complex problem into simpler, overlapping subproblems.
An integrated development environment (IDE) for Java development, widely used for Java programming.
An unusual or unexpected input or situation that tests the limits or boundaries of a system.
The process of estimating the time, effort, and resources required to complete a software development project.
A functional, concurrent, and scalable programming language built on the Erlang virtual machine.
The bundling of data and methods that manipulate the data, hiding the implementation details from the outside world.
A testing approach that evaluates the ability of a system to handle a complete end-to-end process or workflow.
A type of data that represents a fixed set of values, often represented as named constants.

A web-based DevOps platform that provides Git repository management, continuous integration, and continuous deployment.
A variable that is accessible and modifiable throughout the entire program.
